title: Rain and snow to batter UK as met office warn of ‘danger to life’
text:
13 flood warnings are in place across the UK (Picture: Media Wales//LNP/MEN Media)

The UK could see the first snowfall of the season as a cold front pushes across the country this weekend.

Britons are being warned to expect power shortages and travel chaos as heavy rain hammers large parts of the UK.

13 flood warnings are in place across the country, with some so fast-flowing the met office has warned it poses a ‘danger to life’.

The latest forecast suggest Wales will see the worst of it, with more than months’ worth of rainfall expected to hammer down over the weekend.

Areas in Yorkshire, the Midlands, the north west and south west have also been flooded.

A bride battles against the elements after her wedding at Swansea registry office (Picture: Media Wales/Jonathan Myers)

This morning, Devon and Somerset Fire and Rescue Service said crews were deployed to people whose cars became stuck after driving into water. .

Drivers were warned respect road closures and avoid making journeys along ‘treacherous’ minor roads.

The wet weather is set to bring with it the risk of gales, which will drive down temperature causing frost and possible snowfall.

A burst of ‘polar maritime air’ is expected to bring colder temperatures to northern parts of the nation on Saturday, before hitting the rest of the country on Sunday and into next week.

Waves crash into the Dorset coast at West Bay as weather warnings of persistent wind and rain are issued (Picture: Rex Features)

Crickhowell, Powys, Wales is seeing some of the worst of the rainfall (Picture: London News)

More than a month’s worth of rain is predicted to fall on wales over the weekend (Picture: London News)

Chadderton, Greater Manchester, has flooded over night following the deluge of rain (Picture: MEN Media)

Met Office meteorologist Steven Keates said: ‘A cold front will move across the country later on Saturday and this will bring a marked change in temperatures compared to the start of the weekend.

‘There will be blustery showers and the risk of gales in the north on Sunday, there is a chance that some of these showers will turn wintry especially over high ground.

‘It is going to feel markedly colder, especially across the southeast after this cold front moves across bringing temperatures down from mid-double figures to around 9C to 12C.’

Humberside Police said a number of roads were impassable due to flooding and urged drivers to avoid the area around the B1246 at Warter.
